title: Bitcoin Could Get Ethereum-Style Smart Contracts Under 'BitVM' Plan - CoinDesk
summary: Bitcoin could get Ethereum-style smart contracts under a new proposal called "BitVM." The protocol, presented by Garand Fill, aims to bring more expressive smart contracting capabilities to the Bitcoin network. BitVM could enable bridging Bitcoin to side chains and other feature-rich systems, allowing for more complex smart contracts. However, the proposal is still in its early stages, and there are limitations and challenges to be addressed. title: Ethereum Steps on Another Delay Bomb - Cryptonews
summary: Ethereum developers have once again delayed the "difficulty bomb," a code that will make it impossible to mine ETH tokens, by two months. The delay is aimed at allowing developers to focus on "The Merge," when the current Ethereum Mainnet will merge with the beacon chain proof-of-stake (PoS) system. The "difficulty bomb" refers to the sudden increase in mining difficulty that will occur when ETH 2.0 update is released. The target for The Merge is "before mid-August 2022," but developers have not firmly committed to a date. Other top 10 coins were also down 5%-12% in a day.

title: The Ethereum Premine Debate On Fairness, Regulation, and Centralization - Cryptonews
summary: The article discusses the controversy surrounding the Ethereum premine, which was sold in 2014 for around $18.3 million and distributed to thousands of people. Critics argue that the premine is unethical and favors some actors over others, potentially leading to centralization and regulatory repercussions. The Ethereum community denies that the premine has any effect on the platform's decentralization and argues that the shift to proof-of-stake (PoS) won't decrease decentralization. However, some observers suggest that the premine may exacerbate problems surrounding concentration of ownership and centralization, particularly as Ethereum becomes Ethereum 2.0. The article also presents counterarguments from the ETH camp, including that the sale was more open and distributed than critics claim, and that ownership of ETH has widened since 2014.

title: Solana Opens Doors to Ethereum Developers with Neon EVM Integration - Cryptonews
summary:
Sure, here's a summary of the article in 256 tokens or less:

Solana has integrated Neon EVM, allowing Ethereum developers to build decentralized applications (DApps) on the Solana blockchain.

Neon EVM bridges the gap between Ethereum and Solana's computing models, enabling Ethereum DApps to leverage Solana's efficient infrastructure for transaction settlements.

Developers can deploy Ethereum DApps directly onto the Solana network with minimal code reconfiguration, taking advantage of Solana's native functionality, including parallel transaction execution.

Neon EVM offers a cost-effective solution for Ethereum developers, with transaction fees on Solana averaging $0.0002 per transaction, compared to $2 on Ethereum.

The integration of Neon EVM with Solana has been tested on the Devnet and is set to launch on the mainnet.

The NEON DAO has been established to shape the future of Neon EVM, and NEON is the utility token used for governance, currently trading at $0.214

title: Bitcoin, Dogecoin, Ethereum Funding Hamas Terror? $41M Of Crypto Seized So Far Could Just Be Drop In Bucket - Nasdaq

title: Ethereum Core Developers Announce Date for Long-Awaited Shapella Upgrade – Here's What You Need to Know - Cryptonews
summary: Ethereum core developers have announced the date for the long-awaited Shapella upgrade, which will enable stakers to withdraw their ETH and introduce new functionality to both the execution and consensus layers. The upgrade will activate on April 12th and is highly anticipated by stakeholders, with over 16.35 million ETH currently staked on the network. Users of exchanges, digital wallets, and hardware wallets are not required to take any action unless informed by their provider, while node operators must update their node to the latest version of their Ethereum client. The Shapella upgrade is a comprehensive update that combines changes to the execution layer, consensus layer, and Engine API, and users can watch the upgrade live or deposit ETH directly on the mainnet with a minimum of 32 ETH.

title: The Most Expensive Transaction on Ethereum Cost USD 23.5 Million - Cryptonews
summary:
Sure, here is a summary of the article in less than 256 tokens:

The most expensive transaction on Ethereum, worth USD 23.5 million, was recently recorded on the network. The transaction was made by Bitfinex and involved the transfer of USDT (tether) via the Ethereum network. The fees for this transaction were USD 7.6 million, making it the largest transaction fee ever paid in crypto. DeversiFi, a non-custodial exchange spun off from Bitfinex, confirmed that the transfer was made using a hardware wallet from their main interface with an erroneously high gas fee. No customer funds are at risk, and DeversiFi is investigating the cause of the high fee. Reactions to the transaction have included comments on the incentives of miners and the potential for them to reorg the chain to compete for the fees.

title: Ethereum Name Service Allegedly Hacked by SiegedSec – Here's the Latest - Cryptonews
summary:
Ethereum Name Service (ENS) allegedly hacked by SiegedSec, with data dumped on Telegram channel.

* ENS is a distributed and decentralized naming system on the Ethereum blockchain.
* SiegedSec claimed to have acquired data from three databases, including ENS, The-people fitness, and TMS.
* Data dump contains sensitive information such as usernames, hashed passwords, authentication access tokens, and more.
* However, subsequent examination by members found that the data claimed to be "hacked" contains only ENS names and is non-sensitive.
* SiegedSec's attempt to hack ENS fails, and the data appears to be from a public database.
* SiegedSec is a cyber cell led by the prominent hacktivist YourAnonWolf, known for defacing and compromising numerous websites and databases, especially government-owned ones.
* SiegedSec's activities in the decentralized sector, including the attempt to hack ENS, are a failure.

title: Ethereum Developers Launch "Zhejiang" - The New Testnet for ETH Withdrawals - Cryptonews
summary: Ethereum developers have launched a new testnet called "Zhejiang" that allows testing of withdrawals of staked ETH tokens. The testnet goes live on Wednesday, February 1st, and regular users will be able to try out simulated withdrawals starting on February 7. The launch comes after a private testnet was launched on January 26, which experienced a "rocky start" due to resource exhaustion. Withdrawals of staked ETH are an important part of the next major upgrade of the Ethereum network, known as the Shanghai hard fork, which is on track for completion.

title: Ethereum Founder Vitalik Buterin Credits Ordinals NFTs for Reviving a "Builder Culture" on Bitcoin - Cryptonews
summary: Ethereum co-founder Vitalik Buterin credits Ordinals NFTs for reviving a "builder culture" on Bitcoin. Buterin suggests ways to expand Bitcoin functionality without compromising scalability, including implementing layer-2 solutions and making the base layer more efficient. He recommends focusing on rollups and zero-knowledge scaling solutions. Bitcoin proponents Wall and Wertheimer have been advocating for Ordinals, but face criticism from fundamentalists who claim Smart Contracts and NFTs dilute Bitcoin's primary functionality. Wall explains that Bitcoin could act as a proof system for zero-knowledge proofs without congesting the network, and Wertheimer slams critics Back and Mow for standing against the conversation with Buterin.

title: Grayscale Pursues Ethereum Spot ETF Amid ETH Futures ETF Boom - Cryptonews

This move comes as Grayscale seeks to differentiate itself from competitors and expand its product suite. The company plans to launch an Ethereum Futures ETF based on cash-settled CME futures contracts pending regulatory approval. title: Ethereum Users Propose ERC 7265 to Thwart DeFi Hacks – How Does it Work? - Cryptonews
summary: Ethereum users propose ERC 7265 to improve DeFi security and prevent hacks. The new standard would add a "circuit breaker" to smart contracts, temporarily halting token outflows during a hack. This would give developers more time to react and protect funds. The proposal aims to extend the actionable period for protocols to address security issues, rather than losing everything in seconds. The circuit breaker is only appropriate for upgradeable projects with governance control, reducing centralization risk. The standard is still proposed and needs community and core team approval.
